extent.charseq: Deeply Polarized Iran Heads to the Polls
the leader of the 1979 revolution, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini,
the man whom he defeated in 2005 and who is not, formally, in the race this time: Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, a former Iranian president and head of one of the country's most prominent families
the crowd pouring into the tunnel,
soft-spoken architect who was prime minister from 1981 to 1989
the zoo!" shouted a teenager with gelled-up hair and a green T-shirt, a sign of support for Ahmadinejad's main challenger, Mir Hossein Mousavi
Saeed Majidi, who had driven for hours on his 125cc motorcycle to hear Ahmadinejad speak at Tehran's Grand Mosque

their villas on the slopes of affluent North Tehran

derides economists who blame him for high inflation and unemployment, saying that they are tied to the higher classes and that his goal is to "spread justice."
a small group of hard-line Islamic clerics and leaders of Iran's Revolutionary Guard Corps
